text: do you remember a time not so long ago
when one of the hallmarks of a super
high-end gaming ERG was having multiple
graphics cards and why not you could get
high settings high resolutions and high
frame rates to a point unattainable by
mere mortals but here we are in 2019 and
it almost seems like things have taken a
step backwards and that it's becoming
less and less common to see SLI and
crossfire setups so why is this the case
when gamers are still interested in
getting the best experience possible so
as we partially explained in a previous
video part of the lack of appeal comes
from technical issues inherent to the
platform you see in a dual GPU set up
each GPU renders every other frame in a
process called alternate frame rendering
which makes intuitive sense but not only
do the cards have a hard time syncing up
with each other producing a visual
glitch called micro stutter AFR also
doesn't always play nicely with more
modern and high aliasing methods that
rely on data from the previous frame to
guess what the next frame should look
like and newer technologies how didn't
completely solve the problems that cards
in a multi GPU setup have communicating
with each other on the nvidia side
although there's a new bus called envy
link which has greater bandwidth and
traditional sli not all of its features
such as resource pooling work with
consumer grades cards it was designed
for professional GPU compute
applications in mind not gamers newer
api such as Vulcan and DirectX 12 also
haven't made the situation any easier
for the average consumer you see in the
past SLI and crossfire took a more
active role in handling the task of
splitting game workloads across cards
however newer api's give more control to
the game developer so that they can code
from multi-gpu in a way that they see
fit and although this sounds like it
could lead to games using multiple cards
more efficiently it turns out that
developers simply don't want to take on
the burden some extra workload of coding
specifically for a setup that not many
people are using so lots of modern games
simply are not well optimized for multi
GPU and as if all of these issues
weren't enough to keep gamers away from
SLI and crossfire the fact that cards
are
now more powerful makes multi-gpu even
less appealing although many of us
marvel at 4k ultra wide and multi
monitor gaming battle stations the fact
is that most gamers are still playing at
1080p and a solid single current gen
card can run most games at high or even
maximum settings at smooth frame rates
which wasn't necessarily the case just a
few years ago this means that a problem
that multi GPU has already had buying
two cards and then having a single card
from the next generation come along and
provide more similar performance is even
more pronounced nowadays and with many
gamers simply not caring about niche
setups with diminishing returns or
having the money to even afford them if
they do care there hasn't been a
compelling case for more multi-gpu
adoption and of course being surprised
that SLI and crossfire aren't more
popular presupposes that graphically
demanding games are dominating the
market while there still are plenty of
beautiful triple-a titles that end up
becoming bestsellers there's been a
resurgent interest in 2d and retro style
games that don't require nearly as much
computing muscle to run you simply do
not need a $2000 multi-gpu rig to run
cuphead or Sonic mania and even many
popular current 3d titles like fortnight
don't require expensive hardware as
they're designed for a broad appeal
rather than the best looking graphics
possible then again if you're the type
of person who drives a lifted truck just
so you could have the biggest vehicle on
the block showing out the extra money
for a second graphics card might still
